The '''2011 Alexandria bombing''' ({{lang-ar|}}:ØªÙØ¬ÙØ± Ø§ÙØ¥Ø³ÙÙØ¯Ø±ÙØ©) occurred on 1 January 2011 when an explosive device detonated outside the Saints Church in [[Alexandria]], [[Egypt]], shortly after midnight. At least 21 were killed and 43 were injured.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news|title=Egypt bomb kills 21 at Alexandria Coptic church|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12101748|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=[[BBC News Online]]|date=1 January 2011}}</ref> Although it was initially thought the device was a [[car bomb]], Egyptian officials said it was likely a [[suicide bomber]].<ref name="Guardian">{{cite news|last=Batty|first=David|title=Egypt bomb kills new year churchgoers|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/01/egypt-bomb-kills-new-year-churchgoers|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=1 January 2011}}</ref>
+
The '''2011 Alexandria bombing''' ({{lang-ar|}}:ØªÙØ¬ÙØ± Ø§ÙØ¥Ø³ÙÙØ¯Ø±ÙØ©) occurred on 1 January 2011 when an explosive device detonated outside the Saints Church where worshippers had gathered to celebrate mass on New Year's Eve in [[Alexandria]], [[Egypt]], shortly after midnight. At least 21 were killed and 43 were injured.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news|title=Egypt bomb kills 21 at Alexandria Coptic church|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12101748|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=[[BBC News Online]]|date=1 January 2011}}</ref> Although it was initially thought the device was a [[car bomb]], Egyptian officials said it was likely a [[suicide bomber]].<ref name="Guardian">{{cite news|last=Batty|first=David|title=Egypt bomb kills new year churchgoers|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/01/egypt-bomb-kills-new-year-churchgoers|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=1 January 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
Al-Qaida's affiliate in Iraq claimed responsibility for the bomb, saying it was retaliation for two Egyptian Christian women who converted to Islam. Al-Qaida says the women are being held hostage by the Christians for having converted.
  +   +
Some Egyptian Christians - known as Copts - are protesting at the site of the explosion.
